nodes.description: EBCT (Empty Bed Contact Time) is the time calculated by dividing the empty volume of the bed by the flow rate. A higher value generally leads to better removal efficiency due to longer contact time.
nodes.rationale: Formula: EBCT = V/Q (V=bed volume, Q=flow rate; gpm=gal/min).

nodes.description: **V** represents the bed volume in gallons (gal). It can be provided directly or calculated from the diameter (D) and height (H) of the bed using the formula V = π·(D/2)²·H, which is then converted to gallons.
**Q** represents the flow rate. The default unit is gallons per minute (gpm), but it can be automatically converted from L/min or m³/h. Since EBCT = V/Q, increasing Q will decrease EBCT.

Increasing **Volume** linearly increases EBCT, but it also has downsides:
• Increased cost/footprint (equipment, media, foundation)
• Pressure drop/hydraulics: Increasing D tends to decrease ΔP, while increasing H tends to increase ΔP
• Increased backwash water volume and time; requires verification of drainage capacity
• Longer response time (startup/transition); requires review of handling/replacement cycles
nodes.rationale: Effect: EBCT↑ (linear). Side effects: Capex/footprint↑, backwash demand↑, ΔP depends on the D/H expansion method.

nodes.description:
Increasing **Flow** increases throughput but decreases EBCT. Additionally:
• Potential for reduced removal efficiency (less contact time)
• Increased ΔP, leading to higher pump load and noise
• Higher risk of uneven distribution and channeling
• May shorten the backwash cycle

nodes.designer: Increasing volume extends contact time but also increases equipment size, cost, and backwash water. Consider slightly increasing the diameter or adding parallel vessels as alternatives.
nodes.engineer: EBCT↑ (linear). Capex/footprint↑, backwash demand↑. Expanding D can mitigate ΔP by lowering U_s, while expanding H increases ΔP. Review parallel/staged options.

nodes.designer: Raising the flow rate can reduce contact time and lower removal efficiency. Consider increasing the media volume or adding parallel lines instead.
nodes.engineer: Q↑ → EBCT↓, U_s↑ → ΔP↑, channeling risk↑. Alternatives: V↑, D↑, add parallel units, staged adsorption.

nodes.designer: Increasing the diameter significantly raises contact time while also tending to reduce pressure loss. This is a good approach if the installation space allows.
nodes.engineer: D↑ ⇒ V∝D²·H, U_s↓, ΔP↓ tendency. Verify foundation/nozzle layout.

nodes.designer: Increasing the bed height raises contact time but can also increase pressure loss. Be sure to check the pump and backwash conditions simultaneously.
nodes.engineer: H↑ ⇒ V↑, ΔP↑. Verify backwash expansion and pump head margin.
